author: discodropper
body:
Pretty much everyone will list off some of the household names in big tech, like AAPL, MSFT, AMZN, ADBE, GOOGL, etc. All of these are industry leaders with solid financials, so they’re probably a safe bet for long-term growth. Though they may be overvalued right now (pretty much everything is). 

Other than those, within tech I tend to like semiconductors. I figure that cloud computing, AI, AR/VR, self-driving cars, fintech, bitcoin mining, smart phones and computers, etc. are just going to become a bigger and bigger part of the economy. And computer chips (CPUs, GPUs, SSDs, those chips in your credit card, etc.) are at the heart of all of these technologies. It’s pretty clear that technological progress here isn’t slowing, and demand for chips is just going to continue to grow. If you want to go with individual companies, NVDA, AMD, TSM, AMAT, MU, LRCX are all at the forefront right now, and have solid balance sheets. If you don’t want to put all your money on one horse, a non-diversified, semiconductor-focused ETF like SMH or SOXX will give you exposure here while mitigating some of the risk. 

Green/clean energy is a promising market, but it’s a really young industry so there’s a lot of risk in trying to pick a winner. TSLA is ahead of the pack for now, but it’ll have competitors nipping at it’s heals soon enough, and the stock is currently way overvalued. There are also other sectors of this market that TSLA hasn’t tapped into, and could see massive growth in the next 5-15 years as we begin to wean off of fossil fuels. Again, a focused ETF like PBW or QCLN is a good way to mitigate risk and broaden exposure without having to pick a single winner. That said, this sector may be overvalued right now because oil/gas have taken a big hit during COVID and green energy isn’t quite ready for prime time. In other words, oil/gas are currently cheap and will probably rebound a bit Post-COVID, so you could make money with fossil fuels, but I’d stay out of them long-term and bet on clean energy/vehicles instead. 

I also like biotech and genomic medicine. TMO is a blue chip that basically has a monopoly and is a go-to for all biological research. Pretty safe bet on a well run company that’ll be around for years. LZAGY, RHHBY, and TECH are similar, but tend to have their hands in more clinical trials and drug development, mainly with small molecules and other ‘classic’ treatment methods. I’m sure there’s a good ETF in this sector, but I haven’t really looked as it’s my field. CRISPR, gene therapy, etc. are all starting to show promise in the clinic, but is a really nascent industry. MRNA and BNTX are probably overvalued right now due to COVID speculation, but if they can get their delivery mechanisms to work (and they’re showing promise), they’ll basically revolutionize medicine. Again, if you don’t want to bet on a single horse, ARKG is a good ETF for genomic medicine. TNX is a very young company that’s showing a lot of promise for sequencing technology, so high risk but potentially very high reward. 

Other than that, it’s always a good idea to put money into ‘boring’ non-risky, non-tech stocks. COST, WMT will probably be good picks during the coming economic crisis, and may actually be able to compete with AMZN if they shore up their online interface. V and MC are solid standbys (can’t go wrong with credit cards). Also probably a safe bet to go with health insurance companies. SPY is also a broadly diversified ETF (basically the tracks the S&P) that will be a safe bet long-term.

My suggestion would be to pick industries you think will grow long-term, and select a few stocks or an ETF within them. Set up a rather diversified portfolio so you aren’t overexposed on any one front (I’ve lost more than the market with this last slump, for instance, since I’m overexposed in tech; I could probably use more ‘boring’ stocks like WMT). One or two shares apiece from 50 promising companies is a much safer bet than 500 shares in one or two very promising companies. Keep each at a smallish percentage of your total (I get really uncomfortable if a single stock goes above 10% of my total, even if it began as 1%, so I sell to bring it back down and use the profit to diversify). Generally speaking, the riskier the industry/company is, the lower percentage of your total it should be. 

Hope this helps!

author: UnpolishedPleb
body:
Ah yes all the classic comments about the “tech bubble” and how everything is overvalued. Guess what... “tech” is literally a part of our daily lives now. 

In the dotcom times it was all about lofty valuation on the possibility that tech would be the next big sector. Turns out many years later to actually be true and everyone is pissed off that they were wrong about doubting it. 

Now Apple, and Microsoft are literally at the top of the S&P500 yet some people still cannot accept them because of P/E valuations and it’s logical but I think its hilarious how contradictory some of the statements can be. 

These people talk about how its impossible to time the market or that past performance doesn’t indicate future performance yet there is one thing they are certain of. A tech bubble because of the tech bubble that happened 20 years ago. How can everyone be so certain these companies are overvalued when the sector has lead the market for the last 10 years. Maybe tech will fall back or maybe it will continue to outperform for another 10 years. We just don’t know. What’s certain is tech is not what it was 20 years ago and it will be interesting to see how it grows going forward. Those who say techs outperformance isn’t relevant just want to rationalize their bearish stance on tech IMO.  

All this said the tech sector is  broad and there are fairly valued solid companies out there with good balance sheets. TSM(P/E 27.4) and LRCX(P/E 20.9) are some I am interested in.

author: WolfOctober
body:
The fact that you made this post signals to me that even your gut is telling you that it's risky to having an entirely tech portfolio. 

It never hurts to diversify. 

Don't get me wrong, every company in your portfolio is doing well (even a meme stock like TSLA) right now but that could change very quickly (see TSLA). As one of the unlucky people who bought into the TSLA hype too late, I'm kicking myself.

Can't hurt to throw some ETFs in there to mitigate risk and further diversify. Throw in some financial stocks and some of the bigger healthcare or retail players too while you're at it.

VOO, ABT, COST, NKE, V, MA, PYPL, and HD have all treated me very well these past few months

author: Wearahat02
body:
I hold a lot of NVDA, it is my best performing stock

I’m not sure what to expect from gaming revenues. While I’m personally excited and will be upgrading my pc at the earliest chance, I am not sure how their gaming revenues will be impacted.

If I put my investor cap on, NVDA should know that their new graphics card would be released in September which means next quarters results includes the sales of that card and future quarters.

They guided to 4.4bn revenue which would account for ampere release which is up from 3.86 this qtr. however I expected more from NVDA with a new graphics card and data center growth expectations. 

Still I think nvda is great even at this price
If they can eventually rake in 20bn annually, they’re not far off, at 65% margin and 4.5-5bn opex then they can achieve 8bn ebit not too far into the future

that’s 43 times pre tax earnings and I think their growth runway is long so that figure should come down over the years

I would say even 50x-60x forward earnings is fine due to how expensive other companies are.

I’m more optimistic on their growth than fang stocks and ma/v.

Yet ma is trading at almost 50 times and visa almost 40 times. Msft, aapl, fb and goog are approaching 40x

Nvda deserves the 100x

author: CannonballUnder26
body:
I’d propose two case studies for a general idea: Ma Bell and Microsoft IE. With Ma Bell, they split the company into several regional baby bells. I think you could possibly see this happen with Amazon and Facebook, but I think it’s unlikely to happen to the others. Anyway, this action was not catastrophic for the telecom sector. If anything, the breakup of the monopoly enabled innovation and increased the TAM of telecom companies. If it was just Ma Bell in town, think how long they would’ve resisted DSL or cable internet and tried to keep us all on dialup.


With IE, the problem was that they used their platform (Windows) to monopolize the browser space. I think there’s an extremely compelling case to argue that Google and Apple will be in trouble with this and be forced to spin off their app stores, but this will not cripple them — the vast majority of revenue does not come from App Store monopolies. Microsoft stock has been on a rampage since then, as well.

TLDR: long term investors should not fear antitrust action under current regulations.

body: Earnings gaps usually lead to continuation right away or pull back to 10 day MA and consolidate and move higher for the following weeks months. Look at AAPL,TSLA,FB, this quarter and TWLO, FSLY ,PTON last quarter. None of them went down substantially and are still rising. Wait for ZM to consolidate then get calls.

author: OfficerCollins
body:
They already ruled (EDIT: ok not ruled, came to a conclusion) all four to be monopolies and are drafting their proposals for moving forward. They will likely not get broken up you are right about that. The breakup of ma bell was a failure beyond compare and some of the committee members were part of the antitrust probe. 

Bezos directly admitted that if they broke up Amazon they would change nothing about the fundamentals of the company and that nothing about its business would change. 

I bet they just fine them a ton and make them pay their competitors like they did with Microsoft in the 90s and more recently with the labor antitrust suit where ed catmull got a slap on the wrist for leading a wage fixing ring and other crimes.

author: solidmussel
body:
Buffet has tons of winners other than apple.

Visa, Mastercard,  American express, verisign, Amazon,  costco, kroger. 

But the biggest position by far is Apple at 134bn.  His whole portfolio is 260bn.  So that seems like a win

author: Wearahat02
body:
I hold a lot of NVDA, it is my best performing stock

I’m not sure what to expect from gaming revenues. While I’m personally excited and will be upgrading my pc at the earliest chance, I am not sure how their gaming revenues will be impacted.

If I put my investor cap on, NVDA should know that their new graphics card would be released in September which means next quarters results includes the sales of that card and future quarters.

They guided to 4.4bn revenue which would account for ampere release which is up from 3.86 this qtr. however I expected more from NVDA with a new graphics card and data center growth expectations. 

Still I think nvda is great even at this price
If they can eventually rake in 20bn annually, they’re not far off, at 65% margin and 4.5-5bn opex then they can achieve 8bn ebit not too far into the future

that’s 43 times pre tax earnings and I think their growth runway is long so that figure should come down over the years

I would say even 50x-60x forward earnings is fine due to how expensive other companies are.

I’m more optimistic on their growth than fang stocks and ma/v.

Yet ma is trading at almost 50 times and visa almost 40 times. Msft, aapl, fb and goog are approaching 40x

Nvda deserves the 100x

author: R4N7
body:
First of all 30k->100k within 5-10 years is unreal goal. (Market historical return is 7%/year)

I would go:
66% into VOO/SPY, 33% cash (you will need it for future DCA’s or if good stocks dips)

Good stocks for me = strong blue chips (MSFT, AAPL, JPM,  JNJ, V, MA etc)

author: CannonballUnder26
body:
I’d propose two case studies for a general idea: Ma Bell and Microsoft IE. With Ma Bell, they split the company into several regional baby bells. I think you could possibly see this happen with Amazon and Facebook, but I think it’s unlikely to happen to the others. Anyway, this action was not catastrophic for the telecom sector. If anything, the breakup of the monopoly enabled innovation and increased the TAM of telecom companies. If it was just Ma Bell in town, think how long they would’ve resisted DSL or cable internet and tried to keep us all on dialup.


With IE, the problem was that they used their platform (Windows) to monopolize the browser space. I think there’s an extremely compelling case to argue that Google and Apple will be in trouble with this and be forced to spin off their app stores, but this will not cripple them — the vast majority of revenue does not come from App Store monopolies. Microsoft stock has been on a rampage since then, as well.

TLDR: long term investors should not fear antitrust action under current regulations.

body:
I moved 5% to VXX today. Looks like it might move above its 200 MA.  And election results will provide some volatility to sell it higher.  

Or have some cash 5 to 10% on the sideline to gobble up stocks if they drop.  It will be short lived if see a 3 to 10% correction.

author: WolfOctober
body:
The fact that you made this post signals to me that even your gut is telling you that it's risky to having an entirely tech portfolio. 

It never hurts to diversify. 

Don't get me wrong, every company in your portfolio is doing well (even a meme stock like TSLA) right now but that could change very quickly (see TSLA). As one of the unlucky people who bought into the TSLA hype too late, I'm kicking myself.

Can't hurt to throw some ETFs in there to mitigate risk and further diversify. Throw in some financial stocks and some of the bigger healthcare or retail players too while you're at it.

VOO, ABT, COST, NKE, V, MA, PYPL, and HD have all treated me very well these past few months

author: nycgarbage
body: And then what? We push TSLA P/E ratios to 2000+? Lol... The market in June and the market today aren't even remotely similar. You just had a massive rotation/re-balancing of portfolios happen in the last 3 days. Index's are less tech weighted. Look at this board. Today just wiped a massive chunk of speculators fuel right out of the market. Poof. We had STIMULUS in June. The only thing that "could" happen is this market downturn could influence congress into passing the stimulus bill. There is a massive amount of ground to cover to the downside before we regain our 200 day MA. It's time to diversify, set stop losses or learn to use options as they were meant to be used as a fucking hedge.

author: Smitehz
body:
A few things. The unemployment announcement was better than expected which hurts the argument for another stimulus round.  

SPY hit the 200 day Bollinger band top (+2.5 SD above the 200 MA) which is too high (this in itself doesn't always cause a pull back but it definitely can). 

Trump tweeted about how good things are so the MM moved money out to help argue for more stimulus money.  (this won't last long cause equities besides tesla are the best place to keep money right now) 

Google may be in for an antitrust suit.
